commentBody: This is weird. My stats say I got a Tuesday best of 4:39 today. When I go to the puzzle it confirms a 4:39 solve time. But when I got my Gold Star the time was 5:02, which was in like with what the ticker said when I entered the last square
This felt extremely Monday-ish.

A gentle Erik Agard puzzle?
Is that an oxymoron?

A 13.04
TW 7.39
B 6.44

6016 puzzles solved 
100% solved rate
754 current streak 
754 longest streak
I'm not crazy about the clue for 29D. NOMS sounds like it should be a snack attack or something, and besides I always thought getting the NOD for an award was getting nominated.

My vet says he'll fix my toucan. He just sent me the bill.

(These puns can't be beak!)

FYI

There are no halal carts in the Ozarks...

and we don't wear sneakers...

Anyone else bothered by the clue for the revealer (63A) suggesting that the two instances of the same three letters per theme answer is a "phonetic" suggestion for those answers?

After all, in CANDY CANE, there aren't two CANs phonetically; there's one CAN and one CANE.  Phonetically, that is.
A Normal Erik Agard puzzle? No grid-spanning name of a Celeb from a foreign country, whose country I’ve never heard of? No wailing and gnashing of teeth from me? Oddly yes it is.

Two early week puzzles in a row deserving of extra praise. This one not just for an interesting theme but for two triple 9 letter stacks, not easy to do smoothly that it makes for a Tuesday level puzzle. I think some trickier clueing this could have been a Wednesday. Finally BFS and FILA was almost a Natick for me—I’m familiar with BFFS but not BFs and not really familiar with FILA—it’s a nice change from Nike and Avia though. Wasn’t surprised to see Erik Agard’s byline, this has the mark of a seasoned constructor.

Someone mentioned Erik in Sunday's comments and now here he is just like Beetlejuice, though this is a kinder, gentler Tuesday Agard. Just my speed. Today's song is Yes, We CAN CAN by the Pointer Sisters. No cringing necessary. https://youtu.be/IzZkjjENj_w?si=9i1_GF52nqj9-o33

I'm so glad I didn't check to see the constructor's name before I started the puzzle and avoided the fear factor.  This one was an easy-ish, straightforward puzzle, with a little Agard magic to spice it up.  A Tuesday puzzle shouldn't need look-ups and this one didn't for me.

Thank you, Mr. Agard. Your New Yorker puzzles can make my heart sink, but this one was just flat out fun.
Early week E Agard puzzle? Yes please! Enjoyed it immensely.
NOMS?

The "He and I" being the elements helium and iodine was used quite recently, I think.

Maybe that's why puzzles seem to be getting easier.  Even if we can't quite remember, maybe we're getting several boosts per puzzle by repetitive clueing.

I don't remember ever before solving an early-week Erik Agard puzzle. I CAN't begin to tell you how it confused me. My brain played a trick on me and got me thinking it was Friday. But then the cluing wasn't reflecting that. And how could it be that I'm acing an Agard puzzle? I'm glad there was Wordplay to wake me from my reverie! For anyone else who thinks it's Friday and wants to dance the night away, here's Bobby Brown with "Two Can Play That Game" -- https://youtu.be/Ug6L0GiOev8?si=VUVUDjNX7vHuHK3rWr
4:50 GIDDYUP

🙋🏼‍♀️ hand up for having NOd before NOM. MOANA corrected that for me. ⭐️ 

My husband and I used to solve the USA Today crossword puzzles daily for a couple of years. That was our introduction to Erik Agard. This puzzle was very reminiscent of those days. Not too difficult. Just the right amount of cleverness. Thank you Mr Agard. Enjoyed it!

I was hoping, with one square to fill, that B_S for "Certain significant others, informally" might be BFS, and it was. FILAS is an actual sneaker brand!

I can still do Tuesdays without Autocheck, but how much longer?
I was thinking about dance revealed, "can can" Shoprite can can commercial https://share.google/CeoAI4a0m5Q93EsLj

Loved the reveal! I got it. Lovely puzzle. I flowed through it without even a speed bump. It was delightful. I throughly enjoyed 47D. All of the wordplay was fun. Not difficult, but required a moment to consider possibilities. Easing into my favorite puzzle day, Wednesday. In the meantime, stay cool, safe, and hydrate. ✌️
Heels was not the five letter word that first came to mind for that clue
Got my best Tuesday time ever (ten min less than average) on this one with no hints or lookups. Nice!! For once, no frustration felt, only triumph!
Nice breezy solve for me. Great theme. I CAN CAN do it. YES WE CAN CAN.
Is Erik Agard alright?
Really enjoyed this one. Nice and easy for a Tuesday morning. Always pleased to login and see it’s NOT a Rebus day!
As yesterday, a nice crossword with all the unknowns, like NOMS, HEELS and THE CUT gained from crossers. Most enjoyable.

PIEs have shells? Crusts yes. But shells?

Nice puzzle 

Thanks

I'll tip my hat to anyone who was able to guess the revealer.

Double hat tip to anyone who was able to suppress a groan as they wrote it in.

Another terrific puzzle from another seasoned pro this week.
If you ever find your way to Cape May, this visit well worth the time: https://www.harriettubmanmuseum.org/

An enjoyable puzzle and very Tuesdayish. Nice stacks. Two CANs! So cute. 

And is it just me, or has it been a little while since OLE has made an appearance? For a while it seemed like it was in the puzzle every day, but I think we’ve had a little break recently.
I figured BFS was Best Friends, as in BFFs.
Erik Agard can can construct.

Nice Tuesday puzzle and an enjoyable solve. None of the theme answers coming to me just from the clues, but they all came to me with some crosses. And a nice 'aha' moment when I filled in the reveal and the theme dawned on me. Two thumbs up. A couple of perhaps appropriate puzzle finds today. First - a Tuesday from February 9, 2010 by Robert Cirillo. One theme clue and answer example: "Chocolate candy from Portugal?" LISBONBONBON And other theme answers: SOBERBERBER INCANCANCAN BOTTOMTOMTOM Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/9/2010&g=41&d=A I'll put the other puzzle in a reply. ...

Nice puzzle, Eric, but it reminds me that it's time to get off the computer and make that batch of pie dough--off Up North this morning, for four days, and Thursday will be blueberry picking day, and subsequent pie.

No problem completing this breezy Erik Agard unusually easy and enjoyable puzzle. No problem filling in HALAL. But I never heard of a cart referred to as HALAL, which is just the assurance that what's being sold is within the dietary guidelines for those people whose religion dictates that what they eat must be Halal-certified. It doesn't say what the cart sells. Likewise, I never heard of a Kosher cart. There are hot dog carts, hamburger carts, any kind of food cart, but Halal isn't a food per se. I just can't wrap my head around the clue. Pun definitely not intended.

Shouldn't the partner of "ty" be "par"?

PAR-TY!
PAR-TY!
PAR-TY!


Guess I'm getting rowdy in my old age.
Tougher than an average Tuesday by 32%.  Should I expect different from Erik Agard Tuesday?

Did the “congratulations” jingle on the iPad app go away? I haven’t heard it since Sunday. I always turned up my volume when I was close to the finish line in anticipation. But today and yesterday…. Nothing.
Delightful. Thank you, Erik.

Rather minimal theme here, with just 2.5 (CANDYCANE is pretty short) thematic entries and a revealer. Didn't see the theme until after I filled the puzzle. 

The vertical stacks in the SW and SE corners were nice, which compensated a bit for the light theme.
Clever theme and fun puzzle for me, but why so much Spanish?
Will you make us “admire puzzle” merch?

Fun puz! Usually I low-key dread seeing Erik’s name in the by-line, but this one would’ve been a PR for me if not for NOd. (And that was just silly because “Do Ana” would make a terrible Disney-movie name.)

I was speeding through this, was mostly filling out the across entries and was nearly finished, when I discovered that...

I didn't know FILA was a sneaker brand. I permanently stopped watching TV two shows into SNL's disastrous (sixth?) season when they lost Lorne Michaels and their entire original cast, so I didn't know MOESHA. I didn't know that HALAL carts existed (not surprised, though). I had no idea that this particular actor had played ANITAHILL. The clue for ELEMENT eluded me until I already had it filled in the answer.

I did google FILA, after filling it in, just to confirm it actually was a sneaker brand, but otherwise solved the remainder cleanly from crosses and  guesses.
Just for this puzzle, the NYT should have replaced the "San Jose Strut" with this: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gfaYXLDlQnA&list=RDgfaYXLDlQnA&start_radio=1
319 Tuesdays in a row.  Thinking of skipping one on purpose just to stop the anxiety on Tuesday morning.  It has become a thing.
I enjoyed this one. Thanks!

Oof, that felt tough for Tuesday, or maybe the fourth heatwave of this summer has finally melted my brain. Got up at 6 to feed and water the animals before it got too hot. I am NOT a morning person so it did not feel good.

Really got stuck in the middle section: I didn’t know the sneakers (aka trainers here), the cart or what Chicana means. Ditto the actress/lawyer/film, or the ?singer/sitcom. All in all a proper crawl. But, that’s the way it goes sometimes. Chuckled at the theme reveal when I finally got there. 

In Alpaca news; I’ve sadly had to concede defeat on gaining any fibres to spin. The shearing was too late in the season, will not be using him again. The fleeces too dirty because of the drought. Those girls love a good roll in the dust. The lovely guy who came to the shearing rescue had to mangle the cut just to get it off the animals as it was so thick and matted. Ah well, no socks this year.
Great,  fun Tuesday puzzle. Not sure I would agree that 27 across contains phonetically "two cans"  the letters are there in the spelling, just not in the pronunciation, or am I missing something?

Delightful Tuesday and a PB for me. 
Thanks!
Didn't we have AUDRE Lorde just a week ago, and with a virtually identical clue? C'mon, man! Apparently, she's only known for that one book.

Today's grid looked interesting, I thought it might be tied to the theme. 

Alas, it does not look like a TOUCAN, more like a bulldog....

The puzzle was still enjoyable though. I found many of the clues quite tricky for a Tuesday.
For a brief moment, I thought 58D [Follower of Attila] might be "THE" ...

Oh... what the heck. One more puzzle find. Another one with a rather unique theme. A Monday from June 1, 1998 by Evie Eysenburg. Three theme clues and answers: "Question of understanding, to a Spanish count?" UNOWHATIMEAN "What a doctor prescribes, to a Spanish count?" DOSOFMEDICINE "Minute nutritional components, to a Spanish count?" TRESELEMENTS Thought that was quite clever. Here's the link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=6/1/1998&g=20&d=A ..
I hate having to look stuff up, but I had never heard of Anita Hill, Moesha, or Pls... and they crossed. Other than the bottom right, I had a blast with todays puzzle.

Given my bone-deep disinterest in the brands of anything aside from pianos, I didn't know FILA was a sneaker brand.  Other than that, the cool morning air in the midst of the current heat wave must have put me in exactly the right mental state for this puzzle - it was a PB by more than a minute, and the only non-Monday puzzle I've ever finished in less than 7:00.  What a nice way to start the day!

I am feeling motivated by my success, and I plan to do all the laundry, lay out next year's lesson plans, and achieve world peace by dinner time.  Nothing like a good solve to help me carpe that diem!
Felt like a Monday puzzle
5:44. This felt quite soft for a Tuesday and, in my mind, was notably easier than yesterday's. Cute theme, though.
Well done!  Had me some fun today.

Scored a personal best!

I love when puzzles are a breeze cause it makes me feel smart lol, but at the same time I hate when my mind is locked in during the commute and then all of a sudden I have unexpected free time for the rest of the train ride. 

Sometimes I jump right into another one from the archive, but it takes a bit to reset the brain from the last puzzle.
Not to be picky, but “R’s”  in 6-down represents a plural, not a possessive. Thus, use of an apostrophe is a grammatical error.

I would like to suggest a  rewards option for the New York Times crossword puzzle for solvers of the oh-so-much-too-easy Monday, and now-for-heaven's-sake Tuesday too, puzzles.  If you finish a puzzle within five minutes you will get public praise on screen from Will Shortz.
For follower of Attila I tried bae, boo and HoN before getting HUN.
on the mini, DOXED is not a valid choice. it should have been DOXXED.
Does anyone else open the completed puzzle more than once just to hear the ditty that you solved it correctly?  🤓
TENANTS, TOUCANS, and a partridge in a pear tree.
That was almost too much fun!!!
That’s a sweet Tuesday full. Not too easy but not too hard.

Nice puzzle!!! Guessed the pattern (but not the reveal) early. So fun to fill so many long entrees rapidly.

Loved the mini's "mini-theme" (by Joel Fagliano), too! If you don't usually do the mini, it's worth it today. :-)

Ohhhh... what the heck. One more puzzle find. A Monday from August 20, 2007 by Lynn Lempel. One clue answer example: "Fortune-seeking trio" LITTLEPIGS And.. ALL of the theme answers had 'trio' in their clues. Here's some other answers: BILLYGOATSGRUFF FRENCHHENS MENINATUB BLINDMICE Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=8/20/2007&g=57&d=A ...

I read through all the comments to see if there was anything about 62A.  I don't understand how the clue relates to the answer.  EVE?

Anyone?

53
Cones' counterparts in the eye    I'm still learning to do puzzles beyond Mon. TO cut to the chase....Clue #53 asks a very technical ques. with regard to the eye. How would anyone know this, except someone with medical knowledge? The answer i s 
rodes", a very technical term. I find that a little over the top!
That was fun! My Tuesday personal best!
Hi - Oahu is an island to be on, not a place to be in. To accurately capture 20A, it should say Aloha on Oahu.
Never skip an erik agard puzzle. Excellent work as always!

I'll re-post this tomorrow. Just stumbled across one of the most amazing puzzles I've ever seen. I can't even describe it. Anyway, a Thursday from July 25, 2013 by Patrick Blindauer. Just go take a look at it - it's worth your time. https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/25/2013&g=21&d=D ....

I think the Android coders and the iOS coders for NYT games don't talk to each other.  [I know that's true in some other settings.]

I decided to read the comments on my Android phone after finishing the puzzle on iPad because I can see all the comments tied to one thread.  On Android you can only see the thread from the original post, and sometimes that post is way down the list of Reader's Picks.

But on the Android when I'm finished reading the thread for a post and hit the back-arrow, it takes me back to the top of all the comments.  In iOS it goes back to where I was when I left to view the thread.

Can we please have the best of both worlds?  
1.  See the whole thread from any post tied to that thread.
2.  When finished reading a thread, go back to where you were -- not to the top of the list.

Thank you EMUs!

A friend just brought me a package of JoJo's -- Trader Joe's knock-off version of Oreos.
That's got to show up in a puzzle one day soon.  Clue:  [not quite Oreos].
Just wanted to pop in and say “Nice one”, Erik! Thanks.

Celebrating my 100 puzzle streak! Was doing only thu-fri-Sat before I decided a few minutes every day was more fun. Tied my personal best for a Tuesday - a typo in one square or I would have had it. Yay! Fun puzzle, clever theme.
Good stuff! My fastest Tuesday solve yet.

The puzzle was good, but I had a strange issue - after filling it out correctly, it still wasn't solved. I checked twice, and everything was correct. Ultimately, I wound up just re-entering a square, which worked. Haven't encountered this glitch before

@Dave K.

I would put it somewhere between a Monday and a Saturday.  Inclusive.

@Francis

😂😂😂

@HeathieJ

I recently amused my therapist by saying that at 73 I'm evaluating my life, and that I've concluded that on a ten point scale, my integrity is somewhere between 2 and 9.

@Barry Ancona

Not really. His last Tuesday puzzle (Feb 18) was rated Easy on xwstats.
Two examples of oxymoron.

@Barry Ancona
One reason I enjoy solving New Yorker puzzles in a ddition to NYT: it offers relatively gentle, themeless puzzles by experienced constructors--Agard, Robyn Weintraub.

Bill,

Erik's New Yorker puzzle last Tuesday was fun. I like doing New Yorker Monday puzzles as a counterpoint to those here.

@Barry Ancona almost everything he published in USA Today was the same level of difficulty as this one. My husband and I competed against each other for solve times back then. We finally decided to subscribe to the NYT in 2020 and here we remain 😉
Jacqui J, Erik is very talented, and can construct and edit well at all levels. He started here with toughies. https://www.xwordinfo.com/Author/Erik_Agard
@Barry Ancona yes, I’ve encountered a few of his toughies 😅 He’s definitely one of my favorite constructors!!

@Barry Ancona

Makes it twice as much *not* an oxymoron.
@Dave S  Sheesh, I have GOT to start reading the column before I post a comment. SMH.

@Dave S


I agree - I had NOD and that was the error keeping me from getting the happy tune
@Dave S Does it also bother you when SISI is clued as an Austrian Empress instead of an enthusiastic yes in Spanish (or vice versa)?

@Steven M.

I think the point was that NOD is the standard word and he had never heard of NOMS. Neither had I.

@Mike
That Big Bird never ceases to be Amazon!  What a built!  (Two can play at that game)

@dutchiris
Don't try to figure out buitl.  It's built!
@Mike Made me laugh aloud, so I’ll do more than hit “recommend,” and post a comment.
@Lige   I had to get HALAL from the crosses.  Halal carts are pretty rare here, as well.
@Lige I've never heard of a halal cart so I looked it up. Turns out we have them right here in Madison, which is what the AI search thingy told me. How did they know I'm in Madison? AI is spooky 😯

@Lige
Yeah, seriously! What is the Ozark Times thinking?!
@Lige Today I learned: Folks in the Ozarks say ALOHA and have a lot of KOALA bears for some reason.  Something new every day!

@Ken

Was in Mad Town for my 45th med school class reunion in June. One halal cart was on State Street right in front of University Bookstore. The falafel was excellent.
@Steve L the “phonetic” is referring to the “TOU-“ for “two”
@Steve L The second CAN is in CANE. I thought TOUCAN was very, very clever.

@Jennifer R

I also thought "phonetic" referred to CAN. In fact I was waiting for someone else (because I do enough nitpicking) to point out that CAN isn't pronounced that way in several answers, where the A is a schwa vowel. But it works visually and I think that's sufficient. Nice puzzle.

Teresa,

I'm on Team Jennifer.
 A feature of the themers 
is that they each have two CANs, 
which in the revealer is 
"phonetically suggested by" TOUCANS.

@Steve L

Should have been "candy can", clued as "Where Grandma keeps her ribbon confections". 😂

@Gina D

Great.  Saves our ears and your teeth.

@SP

Me, too.  I stared at it for a while and finally decided "F" was my best bet, but I was by no means certain.
@SP During the MOESHA era, I was AWED to see the CELEB “TUCAN Touch This” singer on CNN wearing FILAs, but that attire CANTHOLDACANDLE to his trademark HAHA pants
@SP At first I put in FIFA but the cross required a correction. FIFA the organization; FILA the kicks. I think my mind blocked out FILA because I hate that chicken joint.

@Vaer

Love it! 
I've put on my dancin' shoes and I'm yes-we-can-canning all over my living room. :-)

Thanks!

@Vaer
Still wilting in steamy Toronto but them Pointer girls can always get me up and grooving!

@SBK
Going up to 32C/89F here, again, which is unusual and does feel really hot!

@Jane Wheelaghan

Here's a question:  do you know what the dew point is on days like this?

I hate to mansplain, but the dew point is a much more reliable indication of humidity than "relative humidity".  

I only ask because I very much want to believe that I'm suffering far more than you are. 😀

@Francis
Dewpoint-shmewpoint! My mother (bless her memory) had one word for it - Shvitz.

@Francis
I've never seen anything about a dew point on weather reports or on my weather app. I have UV, pollen and pollution levels.
Having looked it up, humidity is 46% now at 2200 and will be 68% tomorrow afternoon. I never usually look at humidity levels so don't know how that compares with other places.

So yes, I'm sure your suffering is much more. ...
@Solverado    Nominations

@Francis

Here’s what I found for similar ELEMENT clues on xwordinfo.com:

[He or I, but not you?] 4/2/21

[He or I may represent one] 7/28/95

That sort of clue has never been used for ELEMENTS. 

Do you do puzzles other than the NYT? If so, maybe you saw a similar clue in another publication.

@Eric Hougland

Yeah, I think maybe I'm thinking of a case where the answer was not ELEMENTS.  It was something else.

But I very much recall He and I being part of a clue, and the trick of the clue is that they were not pronouns, but representative of atoms and elements.

But I can't quite bring the answer into mental focus.

Help, anyone?

I doubt very much it was another publication.  I very occasionally do the New Yorker puzzle, but very sporadically.

@Francis

Maybe ATOMICSYMBOLS?  Or, ATOMICsomething?
@Francis Yes it was definitely NYT and it was recent. Was one of the theme clues but can't remember the exact answer

@James
Perhaps something like "He and I are here, but not she" with the answer /periodic table/. I too am suffering from clue deja vu.

@SBK

Very close on the clue!  Thanks!

So, I repeat, could too recently used cluing be the mysterious force that is making puzzles easier?

Would we find these puzzles normally difficult had we not been through the recent series of puzzles?  

Or if we were subjected to the memory deleter from "Men in Black"?

@Francis Recently used clues do seem to be a thing in the NYT puzzles, but I don’t know that it is anything new. When I completed the archive of NYT Monday puzzles a couple years ago, there were repeated clues within short time spans going pretty far back. Maybe not as common in the 1990s puzzles, but definitely in the 2000s.  I noticed them because they helped me learn some of the more common fill and up my crossword game, giving me confidence to attempt later week puzzles.

@Rachel

That's really fascinating.  

I wonder if one could detect changes in the constructors and cluers  by the frequency of clues, or particular kinds of clues?

I think I'll apply for a graduate study to try to get an PhD in...I don't know, something?...stuff that really seems to matter but maybe doesn't??....

I mean, at 73 one really feels the fire in one's belly to make a name for oneself.  One really does.

@Francis
Mr Shortz's degree is in enigmatology, as I recall. Perhaps yours could be in stochastic enigmatology. Now that's a mouthful!

P.S. 

Thank you, Mr. Agard for a great puzzle.
I like your Tuesday style!

@Teresa that was indeed a strange answer for those living abroad. I’m familiar with Expats, but had never heard of TAX EXILES. Easy enough to get from the crosses. 

Hope to visit Berlin someday. We’ve visited Nuremberg as that’s where one of our exchange students lived.

@Jacqui J
The Rolling Stones were famous TAX EXILES who moved to France because they were paying the top rate of 90% in Britain. A few years later, Labour took power and raised the top rate to 98% and Rod Stewart moved to the US, and David Bowie went to Switzerland. That's the problem with "soaking the rich;" they can afford to move, and you end up getting nothing from them. Note to Mr Mamdani...
@Grant I had no idea. I learn something new everyday here in Crosslandia. I love this forum. Thank you 😊

@kilaueabart

Exactly the same for me.

@kilaueabart

That is a daunting thought. I understand it from a different perspective... That of my mother-in-law. 

Still, today you won. 

Celebrate every win!!

@HeathieJ

The relentlessness of time, sadly working on your mother-in-law is also working on all of us.

I'm so sorry, for her, and so sorry for all of us.

I think you have the right idea.  Celebrate while you can.

I was voted "Most Morbid" in my high school class.  They actually created the award especially for me.

I am very proud.  And sad.

@kilaueabart
I remember FILA sneakers being popular in the hip hop scene. Run DMC preferred Adidas, though.
@Bonnie Ann what was 47D???

@Bonnie Ann

Was your reference to the nonexistent 47D supposed to be 45D ELEMENT? That is a clever clue. 

I know all too well how the Central Texas heat and humidity can mess up your thinking. That’s why I don’t live there anymore. 

Please be sure to follow your advice about staying cool and hydrated.

@Mean Old Lady, Jacqui J, Eric Hougland

47D was AMBLED
42D was RAMBLED
54D was BLED
56D was LED(which seemed weird since 21D was also LED)
My favorite was 49D, HATS OK!

Didn't any of you get the theme?!

@Eric Hougland

And blur my vision as well. All that sweat in my eyes. My grand kids are here, so I put up with it. Otherwise I would be in CO too.
@Jill Awesome, congratulations!

@Remy

Worried about a stealth stroke?  Or a dramatic hormonal change?

@Remy

He can do tough,
he can do easy.

What he can't do is deliver a less than high-quality puzzle.

@Francis

Maybe he switched to decaf
He can even play Jeopardy!

@Mr Dave

I didn't know that!

Impressive all around.

I would stink at Jeopardy.  I don't know that many things, but I can figure them out with crosses.

@Ιασων

🤷‍♀️

But it fit the crosses and was a word I'd heard before.

Maybe I'm only relatively good at these things because I ignore almost everything other than getting it right.
@Ιασων Yes, that’s a legitimate and common use. You hear it on cooking shows, and the premade ones sold in grocery stores are called pie shells.

@Noemi
As a professional pastry chef, I will agree with you, especially about the frozen, premade ones; but here where's things get a little interesting:
A quick look on the Duck-Duck-Go "shopping tab" at a few major brands informs me that Pillsbury and Keebler (crumb crusts), are labeled as "crusts," whereas a Marie Callender and Chef Pierre (the food service label of Sara Lee) are labeled as "shells," as are those by Whole Wholesome (organic and gluten free). Most store brands--Kroger's, Meijer's, Trader Joe's, and Aldi's (Belmont), etc.--label them as "crusts,'" but whole Foods sells "shells."

And yes, always best to make you're own, but when you have to make quiche for a plated breakfast for four hundred, well . . .

@Nancy J.

Thanks!  TWO hat tips for me!
I got TOUCANS off the -UCA-
And I suppressed the groan since it did, indeed,  Reveal the double CANs...  
Starting a puzzle at the bottom has advantages!
But it did make things a bit too simple....with the exception of the SNeaker brand crossing the food cart.  There are SO many sneaker brands (just when our feet are requiring ever more accommodations--wide toe box, zero drop, etc.) and the mysterious food stand.  (NObody is out on the street with a food cart when the heat index is 109 F.....maybe in states where the Summer climate is gentler?
The HALAL Cart is in its usual position on the southeast corner of Sixth Avenue and 14th Street -- I can see it from my bedroom window -- but the "real feel" today is only going to be 98.

@Mean Old Lady

I haven’t eaten from a food cart in years, but I’d be surprised if the ones in Austin went away in the summer. There have been lots of them around the UT campus since before my college days in the 1970s.
@John Carson Been to Cape May but sure don't remember seeing anything about this museum. Wish I had.

@redweather

It's relatively new.  The highlight is the informative lectures.

Noemi,

It depends upon how you define "a little while."

Sun Jul 20, 2025	
46A
___ Miss 	

Sun Jun 29, 2025	
57A	
Stadium chant	

Thu Jun 26, 2025	
3D	
"Hurray!" 

Sun Jun 22, 2025	
5D	
Fútbol cheer
@Barry Ancona Exactly! It felt like every other day in June, but now we’ve had a 6-week break. I’m not counting OLE Miss because in my head it’s a different word.

Jim, It is a matter of style, not of grammar. I don't have The Times' style book handy, but... https://www.chicagomanualofstyle.org/qanda/data/faq/topics/Punctuation/faq0130.html

@Jim, I agree, but I follow Chicago Style: no apostrophe before the s unless it is needed to clarify something that might otherwise look like a word (A’s, I’s, U’s), and always use it in lowercase (t’s, b’s). But AP Style dictates the use of the apostrophe every time.

@Jim
My H.S. English teachers drilled just that into our heads; misuse of apostrophes. My college Lit professors were just as adamant about their correct usage. I have enough on my plate in abolishing modern clipped words, I cannot possibly include an apostrophe cleanup project. Sorry.
Yep! Both are used. See ngram viewer, e.g., https://books.google.com/ngrams/graph?content=doxed%2Cdoxxed&year_start=2000&year_end=2022 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doxing

DPaul,

New Year's EVE?

@DPaul Eves are days spent in anticipation of the following day. Christmas Eve, if you do presents Christmas Day, you're wrapping and the kids are going to bed early looking forward to tomorrow. NYE we're all celebrating the end because tomorrow is a new beginning (on the calendar at least).

@Barry @JD

@DPaul

And those 363 days are not noted the same way. So tonight isn’t August 13 Eve, just the night of August 12.
Let's not forget All Hallows EVE.

@Margot 

It's not an infrequent crossword answer, clued similarly, so it's one that you might want to tuck away in your head. But to answer your question, the idea is that if you don't know something, you can get it on the crosses... or at least enough crosses to take a good guess. 

Say, even if you didn't know 53A - MOESHA - you probably already have the R_DS and M_ESHA. You can use logic and understanding of the language to figure out that it's likely an O. Granted, names can be hard because there are so many spellings but in general, I think that would lead most people to think of O. 

There are things in puzzles all the time that I don't know but you work the crosses and fill in with logic/experience. 

I hope this helps!

"How would anyone know this, except someone with medical knowledge?" Margot, I had heard of them before then, but rods and cones were covered in my high school biology class. https://askabiologist.asu.edu/rods-and-cones
